conclusion: The problem involves analyzing the acceleration-time graph of a body moving along a straight line to determine when its velocity is at its maximum.
The body starts from rest, meaning its initial velocity v₀ = 0 at t = 0.
The acceleration-time graph shows that acceleration starts at 2 m/s² and remains constant until t = 1s, then decreases linearly to -2 m/s² at t = 3s, and remains constant at -2 m/s² until t = 4s.
The change in velocity over any time interval equals the area under the acceleration-time graph during that interval.

premise: The body starts from rest (v₀ = 0 at t = 0) and the acceleration is constant at 2 m/s² from t = 0 to t = 1s.
conclusion: The velocity at t = 1s is v(1s) = 0 + (2 m/s² × 1s) = 2 m/s.

premise: The acceleration decreases linearly from 2 m/s² to 0 m/s² between t = 1s and t = 2s.
conclusion: The velocity at t = 2s is v(2s) = 2 m/s + (1/2 × 1s × 2 m/s²) = 3 m/s.

premise: The acceleration decreases linearly from 0 m/s² to -2 m/s² between t = 2s and t = 3s.
conclusion: The velocity at t = 3s is v(3s) = 3 m/s + (1/2 × 1s × -2 m/s²) = 2 m/s.

premise: The acceleration is constant at -2 m/s² from t = 3s to t = 4s.
conclusion: The velocity at t = 4s is v(4s) = 2 m/s + (-2 m/s² × 1s) = 0 m/s.

premise: The velocity values at different time points are: t = 0s: v = 0 m/s, t = 1s: v = 2 m/s, t = 2s: v = 3 m/s, t = 3s: v = 2 m/s, t = 4s: v = 0 m/s.
conclusion: The maximum velocity occurs at t = 2s with a value of 3 m/s.

premise: The acceleration is positive from t = 0s to t = 2s, causing the velocity to increase. At t = 2s, the acceleration becomes zero, meaning the velocity stops increasing. After t = 2s, the acceleration becomes negative, causing the velocity to decrease.
conclusion: The object's velocity is at its maximum at t = 2s.
